semantic_identifier: 6852602 - Pinewell Logistics - sales_pitch - Discussion with Grace Pierce

hierarchy.meeting_title: 6852602 - Pinewell Logistics - sales_pitch - Discussion with Grace Pierce

sections.text: Mina Park: Hi Grace—Mina Park here. Thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll keep this quick: I work with teams that are drowning in support tickets and struggling to turn “noise” into clear, prioritized issues engineering can act on. Curious—how are you handling customer-reported problems today at Pinewell Logistics?

Grace Pierce: Hi Mina. Sure—so we have Zendesk for support and Jira for engineering. Support tags tickets and escalates the big ones, but it’s pretty manual. We definitely have duplicates and a lot of back-and-forth.

Mina Park: That’s exactly the gap we focus on. The product is called Issue_Tracker. It sits between Zendesk/Intercom on one side and Jira/Linear on the other, and it standardizes what an “issue” is—theme/root cause, evidence, impacted customers—so you’re not relying on ticket tags and tribal knowledge. In practice, teams ingest thousands of tickets a month and end up with ~80 active themes instead of 5,000 individual threads.
Grace Pierce: The deduping part sounds nice, but we’ve tried macros and tagging projects. It still gets messy. How is this different from just better Zendesk hygiene?

Mina Park: Totally fair. Zendesk is great at managing individual conversations. Issue_Tracker is built for the layer above that: clustering and decisioning. It continuously pulls in tickets, detects duplicates, and groups them into a living cluster with representative examples and a list of affected customers—then routes the top themes to product/engineering weekly. The big difference is it maintains an “issue object” that stays linked to the original customer conversations and the downstream Jira work, so the cluster doesn’t fall apart when people change tags or switch teams.
Grace Pierce: Okay. One pain we have is losing context—like why something got deprioritized, or what we told a customer two months ago.

Mina Park: That’s one of our strongest features: issue_history. Every cluster has a full timeline—when it was created, if it got merged or split, priority changes with the rationale, linked Jira items, and milestones like “identified → investigating → in progress → released.” It also captures customer communications: who was notified, when, and what was promised. So when an account manager pings you, you’re not hunting across Zendesk notes, Slack threads, and Jira comments.
Grace Pierce: That actually sounds useful. We get those “did we ever respond to this?” questions all the time, and sometimes we accidentally contradict ourselves.

Mina Park: Exactly—issue_history makes communication consistent and audit-friendly. And it creates accountability: when priorities change, there’s a decision note attached, not just a quiet change to a field. Teams use it to cut down internal churn—support stops re-escalating the same thing because they can see status and what’s been communicated.
Grace Pierce: How does it decide what to prioritize? Because “loudest customer wins” is a problem for us.

Mina Park: Issue_Tracker prioritizes based on business impact. It pulls in customer/value context from CRM and tools like Customer_Analyzer—so it can highlight revenue exposure, ICP/segment importance, and deal risk alongside the volume of tickets. Instead of “50 tickets = top priority,” it becomes “this theme affects three enterprise accounts and a renewal next month,” or “this is widespread but low impact.” The goal is a defensible top 10 list for your weekly product/engineering review.
Grace Pierce: I like the idea, but I’m wary of adding another tool. We already have too many dashboards.

Mina Park: Also fair. We’re not trying to replace Zendesk or Jira. Most teams keep working where they already work; Issue_Tracker becomes the connective tissue. Support can keep using Zendesk, engineering stays in Jira, and Issue_Tracker keeps the issue clusters and history in sync, with links back to source tickets and forward to the work items. In other words, it reduces dashboards by eliminating the spreadsheets and ad hoc docs people create to track themes.
Grace Pierce: What does adoption look like? Support is busy—if it’s a big process change, it’ll be hard.

Mina Park: The lightest-weight rollout is: connect Zendesk, connect Jira, then start with one weekly ritual—your top themes review. Support ops uses Issue_Tracker to cluster and merge duplicates, then shares the top 10 clusters with product/engineering, each with representative examples and affected customer lists. That’s it to start. Over time, people naturally lean on issue_history because it saves time on status questions and customer follow-ups.
Grace Pierce: Do you have an example of what a cluster looks like? Like, what engineering sees?

Mina Park: Engineering sees a single cluster page: a clear title, a short problem statement/root cause hypothesis, evidence (a handful of the most representative tickets), impact metrics (volume, affected customers, segment/revenue exposure), and then linked Jira items. As work progresses, the status milestones update—so support and customer-facing teams have one source of truth for “what’s happening” without pinging engineers.
Grace Pierce: That would help. Right now our PMs get a messy export, and engineers don’t trust it, so they ask for more context anyway.

Mina Park: Exactly—trust is the missing piece. Because Issue_Tracker keeps the evidence attached—actual customer conversations and examples—engineers can quickly validate. And because merges/splits and priority changes are tracked in issue_history, you can see how the understanding evolved, rather than rewriting the story every week.
Grace Pierce: What would you need from us to see if this is worth it?

Mina Park: Great question. For a proper evaluation, we typically do a 30–45 minute working session where we map your current flow: Zendesk intake, escalation criteria, your Jira setup, and who runs the weekly triage. If you’re open to it, we can also look at a sample month—say a few thousand tickets—and show you what clustering into ~80 themes would look like, plus what the “top 10” would be when weighted by customer impact.
Grace Pierce: That sounds reasonable. I’d want our support ops lead in that, and maybe someone from product.

Mina Park: Perfect. If you can bring your support ops lead and a PM, I’ll bring a quick demo focused on clustering and issue_history—no generic tour. We’ll show how duplicates get merged, how clusters route to Jira, and how the communication timeline prevents the “what did we promise?” scramble.
Grace Pierce: Yeah, I’m interested. Can you send times for next week? Tuesday or Thursday morning usually works.

Mina Park: Absolutely. I’ll email you a couple options for Tuesday and Thursday morning, and I’ll include a short checklist of what we’ll want connected or exported ahead of time—nothing heavy, just enough to make the session concrete. Sound good?
Grace Pierce: Sounds good. Send it over and I’ll loop in the right people.
Mina Park: Great—thanks, Grace. I’ll follow up shortly with the invite options and agenda. Talk soon.
